Award.AbstractNarration:
This exploratory project helps high school students learn complex Global Climate Change (GCC) science by making it personally relevant and understandable. CHANGE creates a prototype curriculum, and integrates it into elective Marine Sciences high school courses. Research will examine the project's impact on student learning of climate science, student attitude toward science, and teacher instruction of climate science. The goal of this project is to develop a place-based futuristic gaming simulation model that can easily extend to the other locales in other states, based on local climate change effects, local stakeholders, local economic and social effects to motivate the high school students in that area. CHANGE uses: (a) scientifically realistic text narratives about future Florida residents (text stories with local Florida characters, many years in the future based on GCC), (b) local, place-based approach grounded in west-central Florida Gulf Coast using scientific data, (c) a focus on the built environment, (d) simulations & games based on scientific data to help students learn principles of GCC so students can experience and try to cope with the potential long term effect of GCC via role-play and science-based simulation, and (e) a web-based eBook narrative where sections of narrative text alternate with simulations/computer games. The proposed project will work with 25 high school Marine Science teachers in 25 schools in Hillsborough County, Florida. The project delivers new research for instructional technologists and serious game developers regarding effective interface and usability design of intermedia narrative gaming-simulations for education.

This project employs and researches innovative models for delivering high school GCC education. GCC is a complex topic involving numerous factors and uncertainties making teaching this extremely important topic very difficult. The pioneering techniques proposed for this project will advance science education of GCC. It also will deliver new research for instructional technologists and serious game developers regarding effective interface and usability design of intermedia narrative gaming-simulations for education. Effective education is probably the most crucial part in our ability to cope with climate change. CHANGE will educate underserved low SES and minority high school students in Hillsborough County, and later elsewhere, with a model making GCC personally relevant to them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate Change Narrative Game Education (CHANGE)

PI: Glenn G. Smith Co-PIs: Allan Feldman, Ping Wang, Yi-Hsin Chen & Yiping Lou 

Global climate change (GCC) is seen by educators and policy makers alike as an important concept to teach within secondary level science. This is becoming increasingly evident with the inclusion of climate change content into the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) for secondary science courses, including Earth and Space Science and Life Science (NGSS Lead States, 2013). This project helped high school students learn complex Global Climate Change (GCC) science by making it personally relevant and understandable. CHANGE created a prototype curriculum, integrated it into an elective Marine Sciences high school course taught in the Hillsborough County Public School district (Florida), and tested its efficacy. CHANGE used: (a) scientifically realistic text narratives  (a web-based science fiction novel with educational computer games) about future Florida residents (text stories with local Florida characters, 50-100 years in the future based on GCC), (b) local, place-based approach grounded in west-central Florida Gulf Coast using scientific data, (c) a focus on the built environment, (d) educational computer games based on scientific data to help students learn principles of GCC so students can experience and try to cope with the potential long term effect of GCC via role-play and science-based computer  games, and (e) a web-based intermedia eBook narrative where sections of narrative text alternate with computer games based on climate change science concepts. The project worked with high school Marine Science teachers in 27 high schools in Hillsborough County, Florida. Through comparisons between Marine science students whose teachers used the CHANGE curriculum materials and those who did not, we determined that the use of CHANGE significantly improved the students? understanding of GCC.

We also studied the way the teachers? implemented the materials. Our initial research on the use of the CHANGE materials (Nation, 2017) indicated that regardless of the controversial nature of climate change, or teachers? desire to remain neutral in their instruction, they were not employing the types of pedagogical methodologies they express as being effective ways of teaching climate change science. We therefore involved a subset of the teachers? in extended professional development (PD) based on action research (AR), which took place over the course of the 2017-2018 academic year. We found by engaging teachers in action research in which they exchange stories of practice, shared and tried out teaching ideas, and engaged in systematic inquiry, they changed their practice to incorporate discussion and argumentation, decreased their concern about the political aspects of GCC, and resulted in their teaching to be more place-based.

A major component of this project involved experiments involving the design, development and evaluation of educational computer games for teaching and learning particularly challenging GCC science concepts. In the first year and a half, we used qualitative research techniques and worked with five science teachers to find particularly challenging GCC sciences concepts for students. The researchers designed and programmed computer games to embody these core challenging GCC concepts, and then used a series of formative evaluation/revision cycles, getting data from students and teachers, to improve the games. Later on with new sets of students, we investigated the effectiveness of the game, as whole as the overall academic unit, in improving student learning of the core GCC science concept. We investigated how the computer games affected students? learning, and the validity of their beliefs about GCC, and understanding of the effects of GCC on the region?s sea level and storms. The data collected included students? exam scores, and surveys about student perceptions of climate change science and perceptions of the materials. On exam questions related to GCC science, students who participated in the CHANGE curriculum scored significantly higher than their peers who did not. Also, their beliefs about GCC increased in validity. The nature and design of the computer games had a strong impact on students? understanding of sea level rise and storms.

We also conducted another series of interviews with students and teachers about the role of the games in the learning of GCC.  The interviews revealed that the students perceived that the educational computer games increased their learning of GCC. The interviews also showed that the games have different characteristics to improve the students? learning of GCC. Specifically, the interactivity of simulation-type games improved visualization of scientific phenomena. For instance a ?Hurricane-curling? game helped students visualize the formation of hurricanes. Role playing games made the effects of BCC more immediate and emotionally relevant for students.  Overall, the educational computer games increased the students? motivation to learn GCC.

The CHANGE curriculum materials are available at no cost on this website: https://climatechange.usf.edu
